security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill providing guidelines for skill tool invocation. All four static findings are false positives: backticks are markdown code formatting, not shell execution; cryptographic algorithm alerts are scanner artifacts from substrings like 'crypt' in legitimate words. No actual external commands, network calls, or cryptographic operations exist in this file.

content.user_title: Apply skill invocation rules before responding
content.value_statement: AI assistants often skip checking available skills before responding. This skill enforces a mandatory workflow where you must invoke relevant skills BEFORE taking any action, including asking clarifying questions. Prevents missed skills and ensures consistent, documented approaches are followed.
actual_capabilities: Enforces mandatory skill tool invocation before any response
Provides decision flowchart for skill applicability assessment
Lists common rationalization patterns that indicate skill gaps
Establishes skill priority hierarchy (process before implementation)
Distinguishes rigid vs flexible skill types for proper adaptation
limitations: Does not search or discover available skills automatically
Requires manual skill invocation using the Skill tool
Does not validate skill content or provide skill recommendations
Enforces workflow but does not execute any coding tasks

use_cases.title: Establish consistent workflow
use_cases.description: New users learn to always check for relevant skills before starting any task, building disciplined habits from day one.

use_cases.title: Prevent missed documentation
use_cases.description: Experienced developers avoid skipping established workflows by following the skill checklist for every conversation.

use_cases.title: Standardize team processes
use_cases.description: Team leads ensure all AI assistants in their workflow follow the same skill invocation standards.

prompt_templates.title: Basic invocation
prompt_templates.prompt: Check what skills apply to this task and invoke them before responding.

prompt_templates.title: Clarification check
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to ask user a question
prompt_templates.prompt: Before asking for clarification, invoke any skills that might help me understand the context or requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Task approach
prompt_templates.prompt: Identify relevant process skills first, then implementation skills, and invoke them in priority order.

prompt_templates.title: Self-correction
prompt_templates.prompt: Notice when I am rationalizing my way out of checking skills. Stop and invoke the using-superpowers skill immediately.

best_practices: Check for skills BEFORE any action, including file reads, explorations, or clarifying questions
When multiple skills apply, invoke process skills (brainstorming, debugging) before implementation skills
Trust the skill system: if you think a skill might apply even 1%, invoke it
anti_patterns: Rationalizing that a task is too simple to need a skill check
Skipping skill invocation when you think you already know the answer
Exploring or reading files before checking what skills guide the task

faq.question: When should I invoke this skill?
faq.answer: Invoke this skill at the start of every conversation to establish the skill-first workflow.

faq.question: Do I need to read skill files manually?
faq.answer: Never use the Read tool on skill files. Always use the Skill tool to invoke and follow skills.

faq.question: What if I am unsure which skills apply?
faq.answer: If there is even a 1% chance a skill applies, invoke it. Over-invoking is better than under-invoking.

faq.question: Can I skip skills for simple tasks?
faq.answer: No. Simple tasks can become complex. The skill is mandatory for all tasks, no exceptions.

faq.question: How do I handle conflicting skill guidance?
faq.answer: Follow the skill priority order: process skills first, then implementation skills.

faq.question: What counts as rationalization?
faq.answer: Thoughts like 'I can just check this file first' or 'this is too simple' are red flags meaning STOP and check skills.
